clusters.title: Former FBI Director James Comey indicted on 2 counts
clusters.neutral_headline: James Comey Indicted on Two Charges, Vows to Fight

items.title: Former FBI Director James Comey indicted on 2 counts
items.standfirst: President Trump's Justice Department has brought criminal charges against James Comey, indicting him on two counts, though a federal grand jury rejected one count.
items.content: President Trump's Justice Department has brought criminal charges against James Comey, indicting him on two counts, though a federal grand jury rejected one count.

items.title: Former FBI Director James Comey posts video statement, vows to fight charges
items.standfirst: James Comey posted a video to Instagram following the Justice Department's indictment on two charges, one count of making false statements and one count of obstruction of justice.
items.content: James Comey posted a video to Instagram following the Justice Department's indictment on two charges, one count of making false statements and one count of obstruction of justice.

items.title: Former FBI director James Comey indicted on two charges
items.standfirst: James Comey says he is innocent after being accused of lying to Congress in 2020 while testifying about leaks to the media.
items.content: James Comey says he is innocent after being accused of lying to Congress in 2020 while testifying about leaks to the media.

items.title: Ex-FBI Director James Comey indicted on charges of lying to Congress and obstruction
How James Comey moved to the top of Trump’s list of enemies
items.standfirst: The former FBI director was fired by Trump in 2017, and has been a longtime target for the presidentDonald Trump’s long public campaign to get someone in his administration to bring criminal charges against James Comey, the former FBI director he fired in 2017, finally succeeded on Thursday, but the president has been so public about his loathing of the indicted man, and his desire to see him jailed, that it might be hard for prosecutors to convince a jury that the case was not brought for political reasons.Comey was fired by Trump in 2017 after he reportedly refused a request to pledge his loyalty to the newly elected president, and then publicly confirmed to Congress that the FBI was conducting a counterintelligence investigation of Russian efforts to help Trump get elected in 2016. Continue reading...
items.content: The former FBI director was fired by Trump in 2017, and has been a longtime target for the presidentDonald Trump’s long public campaign to get someone in his administration to bring criminal charges against James Comey, the former FBI director he fired in 2017, finally succeeded on Thursday, but the president has been so public about his loathing of the indicted man, and his desire to see him jailed, that it might be hard for prosecutors to convince a jury that the case was not brought for political reasons.Comey was fired by Trump in 2017 after he reportedly refused a request to pledge his loyalty to the newly elected president, and then publicly confirmed to Congress that the FBI was conducting a counterintelligence investigation of Russian efforts to help Trump get elected in 2016. Continue reading...

items.title: Ex-FBI director James Comey indicted on two charges as Trump pushes to prosecute political enemies
items.standfirst: Comey, one of Trump’s frequent targets, indicted on counts of making false statements and obstruction of a congressional proceedingJames Comey, the former FBI director and one of Donald Trump’s most frequent targets, was indicted on Thursday on one count of making a false statement to Congress and one count of obstruction of a congressional proceeding, the latest move in the president’s retribution campaign against his political adversaries.The indictment, filed in federal district court in Alexandria, Virginia, shows Comey’s charges centred on whether he lied and misled lawmakers during testimony in September 2020 about the Russia investigation. Continue reading...
items.content: Comey, one of Trump’s frequent targets, indicted on counts of making false statements and obstruction of a congressional proceedingJames Comey, the former FBI director and one of Donald Trump’s most frequent targets, was indicted on Thursday on one count of making a false statement to Congress and one count of obstruction of a congressional proceeding, the latest move in the president’s retribution campaign against his political adversaries.The indictment, filed in federal district court in Alexandria, Virginia, shows Comey’s charges centred on whether he lied and misled lawmakers during testimony in September 2020 about the Russia investigation. Continue reading...

items.title: Former FBI Director James Comey responds to his indictment: "I'm not afraid"
items.standfirst: Former FBI Director James Comey has been indicted. He is charged with one count of making false statements and another count of obstruction of justice. Comey himself posted a video to Instagram sharing his response to the news. Scott Fredericksen, defense attorney and former federal prosecutor, joins CBS News with more.

items.title: James Comey responds after Trump indictment: ‘Let’s have a trial’

items.standfirst: Former FBI Director James Comey has been indicted on one count of making false statements and one count of obstruction of justice. CBS News justice correspondent Scott MacFarlane has more on the charges and former federal prosecutor Scott Fredericksen joins CBS News with his reaction.
items.content: Former FBI Director James Comey has been indicted on one count of making false statements and one count of obstruction of justice. CBS News justice correspondent Scott MacFarlane has more on the charges and former federal prosecutor Scott Fredericksen joins CBS News with his reaction.

items.title: Former FBI boss indicted as Trump escalates legal retribution campaign
items.standfirst: Former FBI chief James Comey, a vocal critic of Donald Trump, was indicted Thursday on two criminal counts as the US president pressed a legal offensive against political rivals. The move followed Trump’s public call for Attorney General Pam Bondi to act against Comey and other perceived enemies.
items.content: Former FBI chief James Comey, a vocal critic of Donald Trump, was indicted Thursday on two criminal counts as the US president pressed a legal offensive against political rivals. The move followed Trump’s public call for Attorney General Pam Bondi to act against Comey and other perceived enemies.

ai_summary: Former FBI Director James Comey was indicted on two charges by the Justice Department.
The charges include making false statements and obstruction of a congressional proceeding.
Comey posted a video statement, vowing to fight the charges against him.
The indictment follows a long-running public campaign by Donald Trump.
Trump fired Comey in 2017 and has been a frequent critic since.

items.title: Murdoch, Ellison and China: what we know about the US’s TikTok deal
items.standfirst: TikTok’s future in the US has been in limbo for over year, but Trump says Washington and Beijing finally have a dealThe White House has confirmed a deal to transfer ownership of TikTok to a group of US investors.Donald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday that creates a structure for the investors to take over operations of the Chinese social media company in the US. Continue reading...

items.title: US President Donald Trump signs order outlining TikTok sale plan
items.standfirst: The new deal comes after the White House delayed enforcement of the ban of the short-form video app four times.
items.content: The new deal comes after the White House delayed enforcement of the ban of the short-form video app four times.

items.title: Trump signs executive order to transfer TikTok to US owners
items.standfirst: Agreement separates app from Chinese owner ByteDance and allows US investors to take 80% stakeDonald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday outlining the terms of a deal to transfer TikTok to a US owner.Trump said he and China’s president Xi Jinping had come to an agreement to allow TikTok to continue operating in the US, separating the social media platform from its Chinese owner ByteDance. Trump said the deal complies with a law that would have forced the shutdown of the app for American users had it not been divested and sold to a US owner. Continue reading...
items.content: Agreement separates app from Chinese owner ByteDance and allows US investors to take 80% stakeDonald Trump signed an executive order on Thursday outlining the terms of a deal to transfer TikTok to a US owner.Trump said he and China’s president Xi Jinping had come to an agreement to allow TikTok to continue operating in the US, separating the social media platform from its Chinese owner ByteDance. Trump said the deal complies with a law that would have forced the shutdown of the app for American users had it not been divested and sold to a US owner. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump advances TikTok deal with new executive order
items.standfirst: The new order says that the deal to turn over a majority stake in TikTok to a group of U.S. investors meets the terms ordered by Congress, and will allow it to stay online in the U.S.
items.content: The new order says that the deal to turn over a majority stake in TikTok to a group of U.S. investors meets the terms ordered by Congress, and will allow it to stay online in the U.S.(Image credit: Mario Tama)

items.title: Trump Executive Order Will Hand TikTok Over to US Investors
items.standfirst: After five deadline extensions and several rounds of negotiations, President Trump signed an executive order to put TikTok’s US operations in the hands of Oracle and other American investors.
items.content: After five deadline extensions and several rounds of negotiations, President Trump signed an executive order to put TikTok’s US operations in the hands of Oracle and other American investors.

items.title: Trump Signs TikTok Order With US App Valued at $14 Billion
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump advanced plans for American investors to buy TikTok’s US operations from its Chinese owner ByteDance Ltd., with officials setting a potential value of $14 billion and outlining measures to ensure security of the new venture.
items.content: President Donald Trump advanced plans for American investors to buy TikTok’s US operations from its Chinese owner ByteDance Ltd., with officials setting a potential value of $14 billion and outlining measures to ensure security of the new venture.

items.title: Trump signs order on TikTok to pave way for US ownership
items.standfirst: Donald Trump has signed an executive order on TikTok, which will allow the app to continue to operate in the United States.
items.content: Donald Trump has signed an executive order on TikTok, which will allow the app to continue to operate in the United States.

items.title: Murdoch’s TikTok? Trump offers allies another lever of media control
items.standfirst: Under the known terms of the deal with China, TikTok would get a new board, including Murdochs and EllisonsDonald Trump revealed last week the US and China are close to inking a deal to let TikTok continue operating in the US. Details are not final, but should the agreement go through as has been reported, the owners of the US’s most powerful cable TV channels may soon also steer the nation’s most influential social network. The arrangement would gift Trump’s billionaire allies a degree of control over US media that would be vast and unprecedented.Here’s what we know. Under the known terms of the deal, which Trump declared has the tentative buy-in of Chinese president Xi Jinping, TikTok in the US would get a new group of US investors, led by the US software giant Oracle, which would license TikTok’s vaunted recommendation algorithm and take over its security. Continue reading...
items.content: Under the known terms of the deal with China, TikTok would get a new board, including Murdochs and EllisonsDonald Trump revealed last week the US and China are close to inking a deal to let TikTok continue operating in the US. Details are not final, but should the agreement go through as has been reported, the owners of the US’s most powerful cable TV channels may soon also steer the nation’s most influential social network. The arrangement would gift Trump’s billionaire allies a degree of control over US media that would be vast and unprecedented.Here’s what we know. Under the known terms of the deal, which Trump declared has the tentative buy-in of Chinese president Xi Jinping, TikTok in the US would get a new group of US investors, led by the US software giant Oracle, which would license TikTok’s vaunted recommendation algorithm and take over its security. Continue reading...

ai_summary: President Trump signed an executive order formalizing the TikTok sale agreement.
The order values the new U.S. company at approximately $14 billion.
The deal allows U.S. investors to take control of TikTok's operations.
The agreement separates the app from its Chinese owner, ByteDance.
The White House delayed enforcement of the TikTok ban multiple times.

clusters.title: Trump slaps 100% tariffs on drugs, trucks and furniture in revived trade war
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Announces New Tariffs on Drugs, Trucks, and Furniture

items.title: Trump slaps 100% tariffs on drugs, trucks and furniture in revived trade war
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Thursday announced steep tariffs on pharmaceuticals, heavy trucks, home fixtures and furniture, escalating his global trade war. The measures, effective Oct. 1, mark Trump’s toughest trade action since April’s sweeping reciprocal duties on nearly all US trading partners.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Thursday announced steep tariffs on pharmaceuticals, heavy trucks, home fixtures and furniture, escalating his global trade war. The measures, effective Oct. 1, mark Trump’s toughest trade action since April’s sweeping reciprocal duties on nearly all US trading partners.

items.title: Trump announces new tariffs on drugs, trucks and kitchen cabinets
items.standfirst: The US president said the move aims to help protect American manufacturers from foreign imports.
items.content: The US president said the move aims to help protect American manufacturers from foreign imports.

items.title: Trump says US will impose new tariffs on heavy trucks, drugs and kitchen cabinets
items.standfirst: President announces 100% tariffs on imported branded drugs, 25% on heavy-duty trucks and 50% on cabinetsDonald Trump on Thursday announced a new round of punishing tariffs, saying the United States will impose a 100% tariffs on imported branded drugs, 25% tariff on imports of all heavy-duty trucks and 50% tariffs on kitchen cabinets.The US president also said he would start charging a 50% tariff on bathroom vanities and a 30% tariff on upholstered furniture next week, with all the new duties to take effect from 1 October. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: President Trump announced new tariffs on imported pharmaceuticals, trucks, and furniture.
Tariffs include 100% on branded drugs, 25% on heavy-duty trucks, and 50% on cabinets.
The tariffs are effective starting October 1, 2024.
The move aims to protect American manufacturers from foreign imports.
Trump also threatened tariffs on drugmakers not building U.S. plants.

clusters.title: Amazon to pay $2.5 billion for allegedly duping millions to sign up for Prime
clusters.neutral_headline: Amazon to Pay $2.5 Billion for Allegedly Duping Prime Customers

items.title: Amazon to pay $2.5 billion for allegedly duping millions to sign up for Prime
items.standfirst: Around 35 million Prime customers will be eligible for payout from a $1.5 billion fund, the Federal Trade Commission said.
items.content: Around 35 million Prime customers will be eligible for payout from a $1.5 billion fund, the Federal Trade Commission said.

items.title: How and when you'll get a refund from the Amazon Prime, FTC settlement

He'll do time... even during his appeal. That's on top of his electronic bracelet he wore in a seperate case of eavesdropping on magistrates. "I'm innocent," insists the conservative leader...

items.title: Sarkozy’s spectacular downfall marks turning point in France’s struggle against graft
items.standfirst: Experts say political legacy of former president convicted of criminal conspiracy now appears impossible to rebuildNicolas Sarkozy given five-year prison sentence after Libya trialWhen a Paris court handed Nicolas Sarkozy a five-year prison sentence on Thursday – for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to get election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi – it was a historic moment for modern France.The rightwing Sarkozy, who served as president between 2007 and 2012, was known in office not just for his hard line on immigration and national identity but for championing harsher sentencing for delinquents. He is now expected to enter jail within a matter of months. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say political legacy of former president convicted of criminal conspiracy now appears impossible to rebuildNicolas Sarkozy given five-year prison sentence after Libya trialWhen a Paris court handed Nicolas Sarkozy a five-year prison sentence on Thursday – for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to get election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi – it was a historic moment for modern France.The rightwing Sarkozy, who served as president between 2007 and 2012, was known in office not just for his hard line on immigration and national identity but for championing harsher sentencing for delinquents. He is now expected to enter jail within a matter of months. Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy says he will ‘sleep in jail but with head held high’ after conviction
items.standfirst: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would “sleep in jail but with my head held high” after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy – the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would “sleep in jail but with my head held high” after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy – the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy says he will ‘sleep in prison, but with head held high’ following guilty verdict in Libya trial – as it happened
items.standfirst: Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy for receiving millions of euros from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi and will spend time in custody even if he appealsHere is a bit more on that from Reuters:Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with Gaddafi in 2005, when he was France’s interior minister, to obtain campaign financing in exchange for supporting the then-isolated Libyan government on the international stage.… Continue reading...
items.content: Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy for receiving millions of euros from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi and will spend time in custody even if he appealsHere is a bit more on that from Reuters:Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with Gaddafi in 2005, when he was France’s interior minister, to obtain campaign financing in exchange for supporting the then-isolated Libyan government on the international stage.… Continue reading...

items.title: From power to prison: The stunning downfall of France's former president Nicolas Sarkozy
items.standfirst: Nicolas Sarkozy, once a dynamic and controversial leader who promised to transform France, has been sentenced to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy tied to illegal campaign funding from Libya. This marks a stunning fall for Sarkozy, who has faced numerous legal battles since leaving office in 2012 and now becomes the first French head of state to face jail time in decades.
items.content: Nicolas Sarkozy, once a dynamic and controversial leader who promised to transform France, has been sentenced to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy tied to illegal campaign funding from Libya. This marks a stunning fall for Sarkozy, who has faced numerous legal battles since leaving office in 2012 and now becomes the first French head of state to face jail time in decades.

items.title: French ex-president Sarkozy says he is innocent in Libya trial, will appeal conviction
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Thursday he was innocent and that he would appeal a court's decision to sentence him to five years in prison. A judge found Sarkozy guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted him on other corruption charges in a trial over efforts to procure funds for his 2007 presidential bid from Libya during the rule of Muammar Gaddafi. FRANCE 24's journalists have the analysis.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Thursday he was innocent and that he would appeal a court's decision to sentence him to five years in prison. A judge found Sarkozy guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted him on other corruption charges in a trial over efforts to procure funds for his 2007 presidential bid from Libya during the rule of Muammar Gaddafi. FRANCE 24's journalists have the analysis.

items.content: Shareholders want ABC owner to turn over documents related to decision to temporarily suspend late-night showA group of Disney investors is asking the company to turn over documents related to the company’s decision to temporarily suspend Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night show, amid charges the media company may have been “complicit in succumbing” to media censorship.The investors, composed of lawyers for the American Federation of Teachers and Reporters Without Borders, noted that Disney’s stock “suffered significant declines in response to the company’s abrupt decision to suspend Mr. Kimmel and his show”, it said in a letter to Disney. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Disney shareholders are demanding records related to Kimmel's suspension.
The suspension followed pressure from the Trump administration.
The American Federation of Teachers and Reporters Without Borders are involved.
Disney's stock suffered declines after the decision to suspend Kimmel.
Investors suspect Disney may have been complicit in media censorship.

clusters.title: Ancient skull from China redraws human family tree, researchers say
clusters.neutral_headline: Ancient skull from China rewrites human evolution

items.title: Ancient skull from China redraws human family tree, researchers say
items.standfirst: A newly reconstructed 1-million-year-old skull from central China may rewrite key chapters of human evolution. Researchers say the fossil, Yunxian 2, represents the earliest known member of a lineage that includes the Denisovans – suggesting our species diverged from other ancient humans far earlier than previously thought.
items.content: A newly reconstructed 1-million-year-old skull from central China may rewrite key chapters of human evolution. Researchers say the fossil, Yunxian 2, represents the earliest known member of a lineage that includes the Denisovans – suggesting our species diverged from other ancient humans far earlier than previously thought.

items.title: Million-year-old skull rewrites human evolution, scientists claim

ai_summary: A 1-million-year-old skull was found in central China.

Our species diverged earlier than previously thought.
